issue.title: Frequent escalate to SIGKILL on shutdown

content.raw:
Could gzserver perhaps just DIE when the user presses ctrl-c? I understand the need to catch ctrl-c on a real robot, to avoid damage and harm, but on the simulator it is just extremely annoying for all users except the one programmer who put the signal-handler in.

When developing URDF models, gazebo/gzserver is (unfortunately) extremely likely to throw exceptions and die, and then it still catches ctrl-c just to be stubborn - after the simulation is stopped and dead. Sometimes it takes minutes until escalating to SIGKILL. Nobody needs to wait for shutting down broken controller managers on a simulation that has already crashed. If you do, I would like to know why?

Switching to another shell and doing "killall gzserver" works, but it still disrupts workflow. Of course, ctrl-\ also "kind of works", but this means leftover files and stuff. 

Please make gzserver respect ctrl-c and shutdown and clean-up immediately.
